es.title: "Un" vs "Uno"
es.content: When counting, you say 'Uno'. But when asking for ONE of something, you usually drop the 'o'. Example: 'Un boleto' (One ticket), not 'Uno boleto'.

es.title: Decimal Commas
es.content: In prices, Spanish uses a comma where English uses a dot. €1.50 is written as 1,50€.

de.title: The Switch (21+)
de.content: German swaps the ones and tens. 21 is not 'twenty-one', it is 'einundzwanzig' (one-and-twenty). 35 is 'fünfunddreißig' (five-and-thirty). Listen for the last number to get the 'tens' value.

de.title: Writing Prices
de.content: Handwritten prices often use a dash instead of '00'. 5,– means 5 Euros exactly.

fr.title: The Math of 70-99
fr.content: French gets complicated after 69. 70 is 'soixante-dix' (sixty-ten). 80 is 'quatre-vingts' (four-twenties). 90 is 'quatre-vingt-dix' (four-twenty-ten).

fr.title: The Comma
fr.content: Like most of Europe, French uses a comma for decimals. 10,50€ is ten euros and fifty cents.

it.title: Euro is Invariant
it.content: You don't usually pluralize 'Euro' in Italian. It is 'Un Euro' and 'Dieci Euro' (not Euros).

it.title: Gesturing 1
it.content: When counting with fingers, Italians start with the thumb for '1'. If you hold up your index finger, they might think you mean something else.

ja.title: The 10,000 Unit
ja.content: Big numbers are grouped by 10,000 (Man), not 1,000. 20,000 yen is '2 Man'. 50,000 is '5 Man'. This is the standard way to discuss prices for hotels or electronics.

ja.title: Counting Objects
ja.content: Japanese has different counters for different shapes (long things, flat things). Don't worry about this for travel; using the basic numbers (Ichi, Ni, San) is perfectly understood.

zh.title: Hand Gestures (6-10)
zh.content: In China, you can count from 1 to 10 using one hand. Numbers 6, 7, 8, 9, and 10 have specific gestures that look nothing like the Western method. Learn these for bargaining!

zh.title: Two vs. Pair
zh.content: For the number 2, use 'Er' when counting (1, 2, 3). But use 'Liang' when quantifying things (Two beers = 'Liang' ping pijiu).

pl.title: Morphing Endings
pl.content: Polish numbers change based on grammar (1 piwo, 2 piwa, 5 piw). Don't panic! Just say the base number from the list; locals will understand you perfectly.

pl.title: The Separator
pl.content: Poland uses a comma for decimals. 12,50 zł means 12 zloty and 50 groszy.

ru.title: The 'One' Gender
ru.content: The number 1 changes gender. 'Odin' (masculine), 'Odna' (feminine). If you are just counting or giving a price, 'Odin' is safe.

ru.title: Writing 1 and 7
ru.content: In handwriting, a '1' looks like a steep mountain peak. A '7' often has a horizontal crossbar to distinguish it.

uk.title: Changing Endings
uk.content: Like other Slavic languages, the noun ending changes after numbers 2, 3, and 4. 'One coffee' is kava, 'Two coffees' is kavy. As a tourist, using the singular is fine.

pt.title: One and Two Gender
pt.content: Numbers 1 and 2 have genders. 'Um/Uma' and 'Dois/Duas'. 'Uma cerveja' (One beer - fem), 'Um café' (One coffee - masc).

pt.title: 1,000 Dot
pt.content: Portuguese uses a dot to separate thousands (1.000) and a comma for decimals (2,50). It is the opposite of the US/UK system.
